(on loan from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = 1996–2004 | youthclubs1 = San José de Calasanz | youthyears2 = 2004–2005 | youthclubs2 = Deportivo Gulima | youthyears3 = 2005–2006 | youthclubs3 = [[Aragua FC|Aragua]] | years1 = 2006–2008 | clubs1 = [[Aragua FC|Aragua]] | caps1 = 49 | goals1 = 15 | years2 = 2008–2010 | clubs2 = [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] | caps2 = 46 | goals2 = 10 | years3 = 2010–2012 | clubs3 = [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] | caps3 = 67 | goals3 = 25 | years4 = 2012–2014 | clubs4 = [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] | caps4 = 36 | goals4 = 13 | years5 = 2014–2015 | clubs5 = [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] | caps5 = 37 | goals5 = 20 | years6 = 2015– | clubs6 = [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] | caps6 = 108 | goals6 = 24 | years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = → [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] (loan) | caps7 = 23 | goals7 = 7 | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 11 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | nationalyears2 = 2008– | nationalteam2 = [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] | nationalcaps2 = 70 | nationalgoals2 = 21 | club-update = 09:12, 3 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:16, 20 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''José Salomón Rondón Giménez''' ({{IPA-es|saloˈmon ronˈdon}}; born 16 September 1989) is a Venezuelan professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for English club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on loan from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], and the [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela national team]]. After starting out at [[Aragua FC|Aragua]], he went on to spend most of his career in Europe, appearing in [[La Liga]] with [[Málaga CF|Málaga]], the [[Russian Premier League]] with [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] and [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] (winning the [[2014–15 Russian Premier League|2015 national championship]] with the latter club) and the [[Premier League]] with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. A [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela international]] since 2008, Rondón represented his country in three [[Copa América]] tournaments. ==Club career== ===Early years=== Born in [[Caracas]], Rondón's sporting idols growing up were [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] and [[Michael Jordan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/club/brazil/205/blog/post/2840087/ronaldo-deserves-more-credit-as-one-of-the-games-best|title=Ronaldo deserves more credit as one of the game's greatest players|publisher=[[ESPN]]|last1=Smith|first1=Rory|date=30 March 2016|accessdate=25 August 2018}} He made his debut in the [[Venezuelan Primera División]] at the age of 17, appearing for [[Aragua FC]] against [[Carabobo FC]] on 8 October 2006; on 8 April of the following year he scored his first goal(s) for the club, in a 2–2 draw against [[Caracas FC]]. ===Las Palmas=== In the summer of 2008, Rondón was signed by [[UD Las Palmas]] in Spain, and made his official debut on 5 October in a 1–2 away loss against [[Deportivo Alavés]] for the [[Segunda División]] championship.{{cite news|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/2a_division/cronica/es/desarrollo/1172328.html|title=El Alavés remontó con toda justicia en Mendizorroza|trans-title=Alavés came back from behind in Mendizorroza justly|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=es|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=9 April 2014}} Almost one year after his arrival, on 2 September 2009, he netted his first goal, in a [[Copa del Rey]] [[2009–10 Copa del Rey|match]] against [[Cádiz CF]] – becoming the youngest foreign player to ever score for the club, at the age of 19 years, 11 months and 17 days{{cite news|url=http://www.laprovincia.es/deportes/2009/09/04/gol-extranjero-joven/255281.html|title=El gol extranjero más joven|trans-title=Youngest foreign goal|newspaper=La Provincia|language=es|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=24 November 2010}}– and finished [[2009–10 Segunda División|the season]] with ten goals in 36 games, as the [[Canary Islands]] side narrowly avoided relegation.{{cite news|url=http://www.laopiniondemalaga.es/malagacf/2011/02/20/rondon-anatomia-goleador/402699.html|title=Rondón: anatomía de un goleador|trans-title=Rondón: anatomy of a scorer|newspaper=La Opinión de Málaga|language=es|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=11 January 2018}} ===Málaga=== [[File:Salomon rondon malaga caracas.jpg|thumb|left|Rondón says farewell to [[Málaga CF|Málaga]], a week before joining [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]]]] On 19 July 2010, [[Málaga CF]] signed Rondón for a record [[Euro|€]]3.5 million transfer fee.[http://www.listandalucia.com/news/sport/transfer-record-for-malaga-football-club/ Transfer record for Malaga Football Club]; List Andalucia, 20 July 2010 He scored his first goal for the [[Andalusia]]ns exactly two months later, in a 1–2 home defeat against [[Sevilla FC]] in [[La Liga]].[http://www.goal.com/en/match/48603/malaga-vs-sevilla/report Report: Malaga vs Sevilla]; [[Goal (website)|Goal]], 20 September 2010 Four days later, he opened the score in a 2–0 win at [[Getafe CF]],[http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spain/2010/09/23/2133624/primera-liga-round-up-sevilla-held-at-home-malaga-stun Primera Liga round-up: Sevilla held at home, Malaga stun Getafe, Villarreal edge past Deportivo La Coruna]; Goal, 23 September 2010 adding a third the following week in a 2–3 home loss to [[Villarreal CF]].[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=302129&campaign=rss&source=soccernet&cc=3888 First-half thriller]; [[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]], 27 September 2010 On 1 May 2011, Rondón contributed with one goal as Málaga came from behind at home to defeat [[Hércules CF]] 3–1.[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=301948&cc=5739 The Beast boosts Malaga hopes]; ESPN Soccernet, 1 May 2011 That was his 13th goal of [[2010–11 La Liga|the campaign]], with which he surpassed the record of goals from a Venezuelan footballer in the Spanish top flight previously held by [[Juan Arango]];{{cite news|url=http://eltiempo.com.ve/deportes/futbol/salomon-rondon-anoto-e-hizo-historia/20166|title=Salomón Rondón anotó e hizo historia|trans-title=Salomón Rondón scored and made history|newspaper=[[El Tiempo (Anzoátegui)|El Tiempo]]|language=es|date=2 May 2011|accessdate=2 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504085755/http://eltiempo.com.ve/deportes/futbol/salomon-rondon-anoto-e-hizo-historia/20166|archivedate=4 May 2011|df=}} the team finally escaped relegation, with the player finishing as their top scorer.{{cite web|url=http://malaga.eldesmarque.com/malaga-cf/52060-sandro-y-el-exclusivo-club-de-los-10|title=Sandro y el exclusivo club de los 10|trans-title=Sandro and the exclusive 10 club|publisher=El Desmarque|language=es|date=20 April 2017|accessdate=11 January 2018}} Rondón started [[2011–12 La Liga|2011–12]] on the [[Substitute (association football)|substitutes]] bench. He eventually beat competition from ageing [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]],{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2012/05/18/futbol/equipos/malaga/1337360836.html|title=Rondón, "orgulloso y encantado" de haber aprendido de Van Nistelrooy|trans-title=Rondón, "proud and delighted" for having learned from Van Nistelrooy|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=18 May 2012|accessdate=9 April 2014}} again finishing as Málaga's best scorer – this included goals in narrow home wins against [[RCD Espanyol]] (2–1)[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323932&cc=5739 Malaga end losing run]; ESPN Soccernet, 30 October 2011 and [[Levante UD]] (1–0),[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323790&cc=5739 Rondon boosts Boquerones]; ESPN Soccernet, 10 March 2012 and a brace against [[Rayo Vallecano]] (4–2 success, also at [[La Rosaleda Stadium]]).[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323774&cc=5739 Rondon doubles up in Malaga win]; ESPN Soccernet, 22 March 2012 ===Rubin Kazan=== [[File:Соломон Рондон.jpg|190px|thumb|Rondón before a [[2012-13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]]] In August 2012, Rondón signed for [[Russian Premier League]] team [[FC Rubin Kazan]], for a reported fee of €10 million[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1845061.html Rubin lure Rondón from Málaga]; UEFA, 5 August 2012 which made him the most expensive Venezuelan player in history.{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ve/deportes/salomon-rondon-es-el-futbolista-venezolano-mas-caro-de-la-historia/|title=Salomón Rondón es el futbolista venezolano más caro de la historia|trans-title=Salomón Rondón is Venezuela's most expensive footballer in history|newspaper=La Nación|language=es|date=6 August 2012|accessdate=22 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809214351/http://www.lanacion.com.ve/deportes/salomon-rondon-es-el-futbolista-venezolano-mas-caro-de-la-historia/|archivedate=9 August 2012|df=}} He made his [[2012–13 Russian Premier League|league]] debut on the 12th in a 2–0 home win over [[FC Dynamo Moscow]], and he scored his first goal against [[FC Terek Grozny]] on 1 September, albeit in a 1–2 home defeat.[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=342386&cc=3888 FK Rubin Kazan 1–2 Terek Grozny]; ESPN Soccernet, 1 September 2012 Rondón made his first appearance in the [[UEFA Europa League]] against [[Inter Milan]], and he scored once in a [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League group stage|2–2 group stage away draw]], also playing the entire match.[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000356/match=2009905/postmatch/report/index.html Nagatomo salvages Inter draw against Rubin]; UEFA, 20 September 2012 In the second match between the two sides he netted a brace in the final three minutes, helping his team to a 3–0 win.{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/355848/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=FK Rubin Kazan 3–0 Internazionale|publisher=ESPN FC|date=22 November 2012|accessdate=22 November 2012}} On 10 March 2013, following the winter break in the Russian Premier League, Rondón scored the only goal of the match as Rubin claimed a home victory over reigning champions [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]].{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/gamecast/statistics/id/363310/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=FK Rubin Kazan 1–0 Zenit St. Petersburg|publisher=ESPN FC|date=10 March 2013|accessdate=14 March 2013}} In [[UEFA|continental competition]], he opened up the scoring in the 100th minute of the [[Single-elimination tournament|round-of-16]] clash against Levante, latching on to a cross from [[Bibras Natkho]] as the hosts won it 2–0 in that leg and on aggregate.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000358/match=2010080/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Rubin edge out Levante in extra time|publisher=UEFA|date=14 March 2013|accessdate=14 March 2013}} On 19 April 2013, Rondón opened the scoring for Rubin, who could only manage a 1–1 draw at relegation-threatened [[FC Amkar Perm]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/04/19/russia/premier-league/fk-amkar-perm/rubin-kazan/1287072/|title=Amkar Perm 1–1 Rubin Kazan|publisher=Soccerway|date=19 April 2013}} In the club's next league match, against [[PFC CSKA Moscow]], he netted the first goal in a 2–0 victory over the league leaders and eventual champions.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/04/28/russia/premier-league/rubin-kazan/cska-moskva/1287076/|title=Rubin Kazan 2–0 CSKA Moskva|publisher=Soccerway|date=28 April 2013}} On 1 September 2013, Rondón scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 3–0 win against recently promoted [[FC Ural Sverdlovsk Oblast]].{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/gamecast/statistics/id/380600/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=Ural 0–3 FK Rubin Kazan|publisher=ESPN FC|date=1 September 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2013}} ===Zenit=== On 31 January 2014, Rondón underwent a medical and joined fellow league club Zenit Saint Petersburg, signing a five-year contract for a fee in the region of £15.8 million.{{cite web|url=http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/ct3/58191.html|title=Zenit signs Salomón Rondón|publisher=FC Zenit|date=31 January 2014|accessdate=31 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202100053/http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/ct3/58191.html|archivedate= 2 February 2014|df=}} He played his first game for his new team on 25 February, scoring in an eventual [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|2–1 away win]] against [[Borussia Dortmund]] in the [[UEFA Champions League]]'s round of 16-second-leg (4–5 aggregate defeat).{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26620485|title=Borussia Dortmund 1–2 Zenit St Petersburg|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 February 2014|accessdate=19 March 2014}} On 6 April 2014, again as a second-half substitute, Rondón scored a rare second-half hat-trick in a 6–2 home routing of former team Rubin.{{cite web|url=http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/team/58469.html|title=Rondon hat-trick rocks Rubin|publisher=FC Zenit|date=6 April 2014|accessdate=9 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409095716/http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/team/58469.html|archivedate=9 April 2014}} On 20 September he added another three, in a 5–0 win at [[FC Rostov]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/gamecast/statistics/id/397886/statistics.html|title=Rostov 0–5 Zenit St Petersburg|publisher=ESPN FC|date=20 September 2014|accessdate=20 September 2014}} On 26 February 2015, Rondón scored a brace at home against [[PSV Eindhoven]], being essential in a 3–0 home victory for the [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League round-of-32]] and a 4–0 aggregate triumph.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-europa-league/match/410561/zenit-st-petersburg-psv-eindhoven/report|title=Zenit St Petersburg 3–0 PSV Eindhoven|publisher=ESPN FC|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}} ===West Bromwich Albion=== [[File:SRondon West Brom.jpg|alt=|thumb|Rondón ''(left)'' playing for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in 2017]] On 10 August 2015, Rondón joined English club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a four-year-deal for a club-record fee of £12 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33852895|title=Salomon Rondon: West Brom sign striker for club record £12m|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 August 2015|accessdate=10 August 2015}} He made his debut in the [[Premier League]] five days later, replacing [[Craig Gardner]] in the 62nd minute of an eventual 0–0 away draw against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/barclays-premier-league/match/422654/watford-west-bromwich-albion/report|title=Watford frustrated as West Bromwich Albion share spoils at Vicarage Road|publisher=ESPN FC|date=15 August 2015|accessdate=15 August 2015}} On the 23rd he made his first start, at the expense of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]-linked [[Saido Berahino]], in a 2–3 home defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Assist (football)|assisting]] [[James Morrison (footballer)|James Morrison]] in his first goal and later being brought down by [[John Terry]] who received a straight [[Ejection (sports)|red card]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33950789|title=West Bromwich Albion 2–3 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Magowan|first=Alistair|date=23 August 2015|accessdate=23 August 2015}} Rondón scored his first goal for the Baggies on 29 August 2015, netting the game's only in stoppage time of the first half of the away fixture against nine-man [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34025390|title=Stoke City 0–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2015|accessdate=29 August 2015}} On 19 December, he was sent off at the end of a 1–2 home loss to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for thrusting his head at [[Dan Gosling]], with teammate [[James McClean]] also dismissed in the first half;{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35078556|title=West Bromwich Albion 1–2 Bournemouth|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Chowdhury|first=Saj|date=19 December 2015|accessdate=19 December 2015}} he finished [[2015–16 Premier League|his first season]] in English football with ten goals.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240499|title=West Bromwich Albion 1–1 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 May 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} Rondón began the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17 campaign]] strongly, scoring the winner goal on the opening match victory against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], then continued his impressive form in September with goals in consecutive matches against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37325836|title=West Bromwich Albion 4–2 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} and Stoke.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37393497|title=Stoke City 1–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 September 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} On 21 November he netted once and provided an assist in a 4–0 victory over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37970618|title=West Bromwich Albion 4–0 Burnley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 November 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} and on 14 December, against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], he scored his first Premier League hat-trick after netting three headers in a 3–1 win, which was only the second time this feat was achieved in the history of the competition, the first being [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]'s [[Duncan Ferguson]] in 1997.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38232131|title=West Bromwich Albion 3–1 Swansea City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 December 2016|accessdate=15 December 2016}} Rondón's goal in 1–1 draw with Tottenham, on 25 November 2017, made him the first Venezuelan to score at either the rebuilt [[Wembley Stadium]] or the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|original facilities]],{{cite news|url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/sport/national/15684989.Alan_Pardew_reveals_talks_with_West_Brom_over_manager___s_job/|title=Alan Pardew reveals talks with West Brom over manager's job|newspaper=[[The Westmorland Gazette]]|date=26 November 2017|accessdate=9 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209194851/http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/sport/national/15684989.Alan_Pardew_reveals_talks_with_West_Brom_over_manager___s_job/|archive-date=9 December 2017|dead-url=no}} as well as the first Albion player to score at the new ground. The following 20 January, early into the second half of the away fixture against Everton, he accidentally broke [[James McCarthy (footballer)|James McCarthy]]'s leg, being reduced to tears after realising the outcome.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/irelands-james-mccarthy-suffers-horrific-double-leg-break-that-left-opponent-in-tears-36511159.html|title=Ireland's James McCarthy suffers horrific double leg break that left opponent in tears|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|date=20 January 2018|accessdate=20 January 2018}} ===Newcastle United=== On 6 August 2018, Rondón joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a one-year loan deal, with [[Dwight Gayle]] heading in the opposite direction in the same situation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/magpies-complete-rondon-loan-signing|title=Magpies complete Rondón loan signing|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|date=6 August 2018|accessdate=6 August 2018}} He made his debut five days later, in a 2–1 home loss against Tottenham on the opening day of [[2018–19 Premier League|the season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45067372|title=Alli helps Tottenham to a 2–1 win over Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Sutcliffe|first=Steve|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=17 October 2018}} He scored his first goal in a [[EFL Cup]] defeat by [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 29 August, with a late equaliser that failed to prevent his team's elimination in [[2018–19 EFL Cup|the second round]] (3–1 defeat at [[City Ground]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45266833|title=Nottingham Forest 3–1 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2018|accessdate=17 October 2018}} Rondón opened his league account on 10 November 2018, scoring twice to help the hosts defeat Bournemouth 2–1.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46081229|title=Newcastle United 2–1 AFC Bournemouth|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Poole|first=Harry|date=10 November 2018|accessdate=14 November 2018}} ==International career== Rondón appeared for the [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela under-20 side]] in the [[2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2009 FIFA World Cup]] in Egypt. He scored four times during the competition – as teammate Yonathan del Valle, with both netting [[hat-trick]]s in the 8–0 group stage routing of [[Tahiti national football team|Tahiti]] – as the former managed to qualify to the [[Single-elimination tournament|last-16 stage]].{{FIFA player|305416}} Previously, on 3 February 2008, 18-year-old Rondón made his debut for [[Venezuela national football team|the senior team]] in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Haiti national football team|Haiti]], scoring his first goal on 23 March against [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]] (another exhibition match, another 1–0 win). Selected by manager [[Noel Sanvicente]] to the [[2015 Copa América]], he scored in ''La Vinotinto'''s first game of the tournament to help defeat [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] 1–0;{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/14/venezuela-beat-colombia-copa-america-shock|title=Venezuela beat Colombia to cause major Copa América shock|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 June 2015|accessdate=15 June 2015}} later that year, he was among 15 national players who threatened to quit the team after the president of the [[Venezuelan Football Federation]] accused them of conspiring to get the manager sacked.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34975551|title=Venezuela: Salomon Rondon and squad in quit threat to board|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 December 2015|accessdate=1 December 2015}} On 5 June 2016, during the [[Copa América Centenario]], Rondón earned his 50th [[Cap (sport)|cap]], starting in a 1–0 group stage win against [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] in [[Chicago]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2016/copa_america/1a_fase/jornada_1/grupo_c/jam_ven/|title=Una Jamaica con diez hace sufrir a Venezuela|trans-title=Ten-man Jamaica make Venezuela suffer|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=6 June 2016|accessdate=6 June 2016}} He scored the only goal of the following game against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] to become the first Venezuelan player to find the net at three tournaments,{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-striker-salomon-rondon-11452812|title=West Brom striker Salomon Rondon makes history as Luis Suarez goes into meltdown|newspaper=[[Birmingham Mail]]|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=9 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170406052552/http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-striker-salomon-rondon-11452812|archive-date=6 April 2017|dead-url=no}} and repeated the feat in the quarter-finals, a 1–4 defeat to [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]].{{cite
